intro: Parablechnum chiriquanum, commonly known as the Chiriquí pohuewe, is a flowering plant native to the humid lowland forests of Central America. It belongs to the family Melastomataceae and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are opposite, elliptical, and have a leathery texture, while its flowers are usually pink or purple, attracting various pollinators. Parablechnum chiriquanum plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, contributing to biodiversity and supporting local wildlife.
